verses.text: A lazy person is compared to a filthy stone, everyone will hiss at his disgrace.
verses.comment: Sirach opens with a sharp warning against sloth, using vivid imagery familiar to Proverbs. Laziness soils the soul and reputation, echoing the tradition that virtue demands personal effort.
verses.sectionHeader: The Folly of Laziness and Disgraceful Children

verses.text: A lazy person is compared to a heap of dung: everyone who touches it shakes off their hands.
verses.comment: Here, idleness is shown as unclean, a spiritual danger defiling those it contacts. Note the strong association between sloth and impurity, anticipating New Testament admonitions to diligence (cf. Rom. 12:11).

verses.text: A father's shame is to have an undisciplined child, and among daughters, any daughter who brings dishonor is his loss.
verses.comment: Family discipline is central to biblical wisdom; the consequences of raising foolish children impact parents deeply. The focus on daughters highlights the traditional role of honor in community life.

verses.text: A prudent daughter will inherit her father, but one who brings shame causes him to lose his wealth.
verses.comment: The inheritance of wisdom and virtue is a theme echoing throughout the Old Testament, pointing toward the transmission of spiritual and practical blessings within the family.

verses.text: A daughter who acts boldly brings shame and sorrow, and she will be despised by everyone.
verses.comment: Boldness here refers to rebellious or shameless conduct, undermining family honor. The consequences of sin ripple outward, affecting the community, a concept foundational to Christian teaching on scandal.

verses.text: Like music in a time of mourning is ill-timed conversation, but a thrashing and discipline are at all times wisdom.
verses.comment: The verse contrasts inappropriate words during grief—like joyful music at a funeral—with the appropriateness of correction; discipline is always timely and wise, echoing wisdom's value in Proverbs 13:24 and emphasizing sensitivity to context in relationships.
verses.sectionHeader: The Wretchedness and Danger of Fools

verses.comment: Folly is likened to spiritual sleep. The theme of wakefulness is echoed in Christ's admonition to 'keep watch' (Mark 13:33).
The spiritual death of folly surpasses physical death; the concern for the immortal soul is paramount, resonating with later teaching on salvation and damnation.

verses.text: Whoever teaches a fool is like one who glues broken pieces of pottery together, or who rouses a sleeper from deep slumber.
verses.comment: Attempting to instruct a fool is portrayed as futile as repairing shattered pottery or waking someone deeply asleep—an image that stresses the folly's stubborn intractability (Proverbs 26:4-5).

verses.text: Whoever tells a story to a fool tells it to a drowsy man; and at the end he will say, “What was it?”
verses.comment: A fool receives teaching with apathy and forgetfulness, likened to a sleepy listener who cannot recall the tale, underscoring the frustration of teaching the unteachable (Matthew 13:13-15).

verses.text: Weep for the dead, for he has left the light behind; and weep for the fool, for he has left intelligence behind. Weep less bitterly for the dead, for he is at rest; but the life of the fool is worse than death.
verses.comment: Sirach poignantly notes the tragedy of folly: while the dead merit weeping, the fool's life—bereft of understanding—is more pitiable, reflecting a biblical theme that ignorance is a kind of living death (Proverbs 17:21).

verses.text: Mourning for the dead lasts seven days, but for the foolish or the ungodly it lasts all the days of their lives.
verses.comment: While mourning for the dead is brief and finite, the sorrow connected to folly or wickedness is lifelong, demonstrating the social and spiritual consequences of a wasted mind (Psalm 14:1).

verses.text: Do not talk much with a senseless person or visit an unintelligent person. Stay clear of him, or you may have trouble, and be spattered when he shakes himself off. Avoid him and you will find rest, and you will never be wearied by his lack of sense.
verses.comment: The sage advises avoiding senseless companions, as their folly brings only distress and contamination by association, echoing warnings like Proverbs 13:20: 'The companion of fools will suffer harm.'

verses.text: What is heavier than lead? And what is its name except 'Fool'?
verses.comment: Nothing is heavier—more burdensome—than a fool, using 'lead' as a metaphor for the oppressive weight of foolishness in community life (cf. Proverbs 27:3).

verses.text: Sand, salt, and a piece of iron are easier to bear than a stupid person.
verses.comment: This proverb emphasizes the intolerable burden of a fool by comparing him to heavy yet manageable materials; foolishness is uniquely wearisome (Proverbs 30:21-23).

verses.text: A wooden beam firmly bonded into a building is not loosened by an earthquake; so the mind firmly resolved after due reflection will not be afraid in a crisis.
verses.comment: Sirach highlights the stability of a well-reflected, resolved mind, which, like a building's firm timber, stands strong amid crisis—a virtue prized in wisdom literature (cf. James 1:6-8).

verses.text: A mind settled on an intelligent thought is like stucco decoration that makes a wall smooth.
verses.comment: A mind occupied with sound, thoughtful plans is compared to beautiful stucco that smooths a wall, a metaphor for the tranquility that wisdom imparts (Proverbs 3:13-18).

verses.text: Fences set on a high place will not stand firm against the wind; so a timid mind with a fool’s resolve will not stand firm against any fear.
verses.comment: Just as flimsy fences collapse in wind, so a cowardly person—especially if misguided by a fool's resolve—crumbles under pressure, emphasizing the need for inner fortitude (Matthew 7:26-27).

verses.text: One who pricks the eye brings tears, and one who pricks the heart makes clear its feelings.
verses.comment: Physical wounds elicit visible reactions—tears from the eye, emotions from the heart—reminding that penetrating another's core brings real consequences (Proverbs 15:13).

verses.text: One who throws a stone at birds scares them away, and one who reviles a friend destroys a friendship.
verses.comment: Insults or betrayals can shatter friendships as easily as a stone startles and disperses birds, stressing the destructive power of words (Proverbs 16:28).

verses.text: Even if you draw your sword against a friend, do not despair, for there is a way back.
verses.comment: Though conflicts may escalate even to violence, reconciliation remains possible—an ancient reminder of the value of peacemaking among friends (Matthew 18:21-22).

verses.text: If you open your mouth against your friend, do not worry, for reconciliation is possible. But as for reviling, arrogance, disclosure of secrets, or a treacherous blow— in these cases any friend will take to flight.
verses.comment: Missteps in speech towards a friend can be repaired, but deeper betrayals—reviling, pride, gossip, or treachery—destroy relationships beyond remedy (Proverbs 11:13; Psalm 15:3).

verses.text: Gain the trust of your neighbor in his poverty, so that you may rejoice with him in his prosperity. Stand by him in time of distress, so that you may share with him in his inheritance.
verses.comment: Loyalty is most meaningful in adversity; sharing burdens now leads to shared blessings later, reinforcing the biblical ethic of steadfast friendship (Proverbs 17:17).

verses.text: The vapor and smoke of the furnace precede the fire; so insults precede bloodshed.
verses.comment: Insults are depicted as a precursor to more serious conflict, just as smoke signals fire, warning that unchecked strife escalates to violence (James 3:5-6).

verses.text: I am not ashamed to shelter a friend, and I will not hide from him.
verses.comment: There is no shame in offering sanctuary or support to a friend; biblical ethics affirm hospitality and solidarity (cf. Proverbs 27:10).

verses.text: But if harm should come to me because of him, whoever hears of it will beware of him.
verses.comment: However, the sage cautions that friendship can carry risk; if betrayed, reputational harm follows not just for the betrayer, but as a warning to others about misplaced trust (Psalm 41:9).

verses.text: Who will set a guard over my mouth, and an effective seal upon my lips, so that I may not fall because of them, and my tongue may not destroy me?
verses.comment: Sirach concludes with a prayer for self-control over speech, recognizing the tongue's capacity for destruction—a theme echoed in James 3:2-10.
